title: From Persecutor to Preacher
objective: Trace gospel expansion to Samaria, the Ethiopian official's conversion, and Saul's dramatic transformation.

required_passages.text: There arose a great persecution... those scattered went about preaching the word... Philip proclaimed Christ in Samaria... Simon believed outwardly but his heart was not right... an angel sent Philip to the Ethiopian eunuch reading Isaiah; he preached Jesus and baptized him... Saul, still breathing threats, met the risen Jesus on the road to Damascus... 'he is a chosen instrument of mine' ... Saul proclaimed Jesus in synagogues... the church had peace and was built up.

segments.audio_script: Persecution scatters believers, but the gospel spreads. Today we see mission in Samaria and the astonishing conversion of Saul.

Listen to Acts 8 and 9. After Stephen's death, great persecution scattered the church, and those scattered preached the word. Philip proclaimed Christ in Samaria with joy and signs. Peter confronted Simon's false heart. An angel then sent Philip to a desert road where an Ethiopian official read Isaiah. Beginning with that Scripture, Philip told him the good news about Jesus. The official believed and was baptized. Meanwhile Saul sought to destroy the church. On the road to Damascus, a light from heaven flashed and a voice said, 'Saul, Saul, why are you persecuting me?' Saul asked, 'Who are you, Lord?' The answer came, 'I am Jesus.' Blinded, Saul was led into the city. The Lord sent Ananias to him, saying Saul was a chosen instrument. Saul was filled with the Spirit, baptized, and immediately proclaimed Jesus as the Son of God.
Acts 1:8 unfolds: from Jerusalem to Samaria and beyond. The Ethiopian likely represents the gospel reaching the nations. Saul's conversion prepares the future apostle to the Gentiles.

Persecution cannot stop mission; God uses it to spread witness. Scripture-centered evangelism leads the Ethiopian to Christ. True conversion changes allegiance and life, unlike superficial belief. Saul's conversion shows grace is stronger than hostility; the church's greatest enemy becomes its greatest missionary theologian.
Key themes include providence in persecution, cross-cultural mission, Scripture and Christ-centered evangelism, authentic repentance, calling, and transforming grace.
Reflect on this: Where might God be using hardship to advance mission through you? Are you ready to explain Scripture as good news about Jesus?
The gospel reaches new peoples and transforms Saul. Next, God opens the door to Gentiles through Peter and Cornelius.
